segments.text: in with what interested in the set pattern of the interview, what interested you in oceanography, and what brought you to this sort of newly emerging discipline, in your case, particularly early.
Yeah, wish you hadn't said that.
Mm-hmm.
Well.
When I was in graduate school in 1939, I entered graduate school at the University of Buffalo.
And I got interested in limnology, which is the oceanography of lakes.
It's oceanography without salt.
And the man with whom I worked, Dr. Tressler, T-R-E-S-S-L-E-R, Dr. Willis Tressler,
worked with me on a number of the lakes in New York State and a bay near Rochester called Irondequoit Bay.
I give you this as a background only because in the New York State lakes we had a diversity of environmental conditions from deep, deep lakes that were high in oxygen to
lakes that had very little oxygen because of all the organic material.
And then on Irondequoit Bay, we planned a year's study going there every month in order to see what happened.
So when I got my master's there, I decided to go on to work on the doctorate.
And as is so often the case, you decide with whom you want to work.
rather than specifically where to go.
And I wanted to work with George Evelyn Hutchinson, who probably was and is the greatest of the limnologists, the freshwater ecologists.
So while I was with the University of Buffalo, I worked for a New York State fishing game to get through school.
And when I went to Yale to work with Evelyn, I worked with the Connecticut State
fishing game.

Now, while I was working on my degree at Yale, I worked with Dr. Gordon Riley, who now is probably one of the leading men in the world on the food chain in the sea, starting with the sun's energy to work on up through the
energy considerations to the Clamax predators, the Tunas, for instance.
Anyway, while I was at Yale, the war came along, and I left to teach in a little school where I did my undergraduate work in Pennsylvania in a naval marine radar school.
And I got hopelessly bored after about a year, a year and a half.
So I wrote to Dr. Riley and asked if there was any chance of working with him, because I came to respect him so much at Yale.
At that time, he was at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.
Now, in 1941, I had worked with him on one cruise of the Atlantis out on Georges and Grand Banks.
She's a beautiful ship, as you probably know.
I have a picture of her over there.
Mostly at the time we were under full sail, I worked as his chemist, so he knew me.
And he knew that I got terribly seasick and did things like going up to the top of the 140-foot main mast and
freezing there, so they had to come up and get me down and so forth.
Anyway, he said, sure, come to the Woods Hole Oceanographic.
So I went with the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in 1942 or 43 and got involved in work on the physics of underwater sounds.
When you transmit a sonic pulse into the ocean because of the vertical changes in the temperature and to a much lesser degree because of vertical changes in the salinity, the sound is refracted.
And if the target is a submarine,
Under some conditions, it can go practically under the ship, and you don't even know it's there.
So I had spent eight long years in college, studiously avoiding anything in physics.
Became a biologist and aquatic biologist.
Went with the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, working with Dr. Riley Allen Vine, Columbus Islin,
Fritz Fuglester, Dean Pompous, Maurice Ewing, the whole school of oceanography.
And under contract with Woods Hole, went to Miami to work on the physics of underwater sound.
Because at that time, we were losing ships.
I could sit in my hotel room in Miami and see the tankers going up as they were torpedoed.
And then I came back to Woods Hole after spending time with Gordon and others on underwater sound.

They got me interested in going down in the submarines to work on the compressibility of a submarine as you dived and the ballasting as a function of this thermocline, rapid change in the temperature and thus in the density.
And we installed bathy thermographs on the submarines
and then went out on the submarines to teach other diving officers how to use the records in adjusting the ballast and the trim.
So I went back to Woods Hole in 1945, I think, 45 or 46, I don't remember, to work on a report

and summarizing what I had learned in oceanography and propagation of sound in seawater and operation of the submarines with Alfred Redfield, who at that time was the assistant director under Columbus Islin.
And suddenly a man by the name of Dr. Cliff Barnes, who's now
retired with the University of Washington and was one of the first men in the field of oceanography to have a degree in oceanography.
Incidentally, he worked for the Coast Guard.
And the commandant of the Coast Guard, Iceberg Eddie Smith, got the first PhD in oceanography ever given in our nation.
That was at the University of Washington.
Anyway.
Cliff came to Woods Hole and asked if I would consider spending five weeks at Bikini, because they were thinking of having some atomic bomb tests.
I'd just moved my wife and kids to Woods Hole, and we were going to settle down after all of this being away from the family.
And I said, sure, I'd love to go.
So for six months in lieu of five weeks,
We worked on the oceanography, the flow patterns through and around the Bikini Atoll in preparation for both the air blast and the underwater blast.
An interesting aspect is they had brought together probably every one of the major oceanographers in our nation.
Our leader was
Roger Rebell from Scripps, who's now with Harvard.
Cliff Barnes.
And Walter Monk was there, who's now the director of the big lab at Scripps.
Bill Von Arks from Woods Hole.
Oh hell, I can't even remember all of them.
Hal Turner from Woods Hole.
I doubt if... Marston Sargent, who is at Scripps, it's pretty hard to think of an oceanographer back in 1946 in our nation who was not at Bikini.
Gene LaFond, who was with the Naval Electronics Lab and is now retired from the government and has a company of his own in...
as a consultant in oceanography.
And while I was at Bikini, I was offered a job with what was then the Navy Hydrographic Office.
Dr. Richard Fleming, who was the senior oceanographer with Roger Rebell, he's one of the authors
Fairdrip Johnson and Fleming was asked to head up the Division of Oceanography at the Navy Hydrographic Office.
So I came back with Dr. Fleming, Dr. Barnes, Shirley Bates, who's now the chief scientist with the Coast Guard at the lab in Groton, Dr. John Lyman, who had a variety of jobs and now
retired in North Carolina and myself were the nucleus of what became the Navy Oceanographic Office.
We started with five people and ended up with over 2,000.
And it was rather an exciting development because, of course, really the only person in that whole group who had a degree in oceanography was
Dr. Fleming.

In the early days, everybody we hired had a degree in some one of the natural sciences, physics, chemistry, biology, math, statistics, but there were no people really with degrees in oceanography because Scripps, which was about the only institution other than the University of Washington that had

a curriculum in the marine sciences in oceanography, kept bringing people on board, looking towards getting a degree, and Scripps would say, hey, if you could give me two more years, we have a new contract with the Navy or NSF or whoever it happens to be.
So John Lyman, who ended up with...
Hydrographic Office with us and then Department of Interior and so forth.
Pritchard, who ended up with Johns Hopkins.
Dale Leeper, who ended up with Texas A&M and is now out at the Naval, what's it called,
Naval School in the West Coast.
Monterey.
Monterey.
Wayne Burt, who ended up as the director of Department of Oceanography at Oregon State, all were PhD candidates at Scripps.
All got involved in contractual arrangements.
All left Scripps to take jobs, then went back and got their degree because they could tell Scripps to drop dead on the contract route, you see, and get their degrees.
I had several questions along the way I'd like to ask you about what we discussed thus far.
What exactly did you do at the bikini test?
I was one of the group that was concerned with the flow of

water through the atoll was in an area in which the other trade winds piled the water up against the eastern edge of the atoll and that formed a hydrostatic head so that the water always flowed from east to west through the the basin of the atoll and the idea was after the
the nuclear devices were exploded, how soon could the people go back into the lagoon with safety?
So that meant that as long as the trade winds were blowing, the water was piled up, and you had a hydrostatic head, you had to flow through.
I remember we couldn't figure out one
area of the lagoon.
So we flew back.

Bill VanArks and I flew from Bikini to Kwajalein to the west coast to Washington to Woods Hole so he could look at the flow pattern by building a scaled-down model of the atoll in a flume at the Woods Hole Oceanographic
And we found out what it was was horizontal eddies at the major pass into the lagoon.
Anyway, the day before the air blast, the trade winds stopped blowing.
The hydrostatic head thus decreased.
The air blast went off.
They brought the people back in on our prediction as a result of the flow pattern.
The flow pattern, of course, had completely changed.
They had to sink the damn ships.
They had to throw away the men's clothes.
It was a mess.
It just shows you the vagaries of what we now call ocean-atmosphere accoupling and air-sea interaction.
Even in those days, we knew something was going on, but we didn't realize like we do as of...

the last two days I've been involved with a group and about all we have discussed is ocean atmosphere coupling and air-sea interaction and the global weather because we now realize that this is a factor that we have to understand or we never will be able to improve our understanding of global weather.
Did there seem to be any conflicts at Bikini between military and civilian oceanographers?
No, there were no really military oceanographers.
All the people that were there in terms of oceanography were civilians.
The only man in uniform, well, there were two.
Well, there were three.
Roger Revell was a commander.
Marston Sargent was a commander.
I spent a week with him on rongelap doing some work, and the only thing he wore the whole week was his commander's hat with the gold leaves.
And there was a marine captain from a museum in Chicago interested in the birds out there, and the rest were civilians.
The prime purpose of the military was to provide logistics, to provide small craft to get onto the reefs.
Now, there were some arguments.
Some of the elderly scientists at that time, I was quite young compared to now, of course, who felt that they weren't receiving the attention in terms of the priorities they'd ought to get.
Well, the Roger Revell and Marston Sargent and Cliff Barnes and the cool heads in command, I'd say no.
There was no overt conflict at all.
Argument has conflict now.
Did the aftermath of the test, except for the combination of title wins, come out about like you had expected it to?
Well, of course we didn't expect, because we had...
nothing to base expectations on.
I went out again the next summer on a repeats survey, and I'll admit I was very surprised at the level of the radionuclides in the hole that the underwater blast blew in the bottom of the lagoon.
Now that was ignorance on my part.
There were those who knew so much more than I did about the half-life, and then I used

Well, there was a man from AEC by the name of Seymour who was with the University of Washington, continued work for years on the biologically concentrated radionuclides before the people who had been moved to the island of Lingenai from Bikini were allowed to move back.
level had reached a safe level.

But the first thing, on the air blast we went off about six miles and stopped the ship and it was just at dawn, it was a beautiful morning and we had the radio on and we heard the bombardier say, bombs away.
we had read in the newspapers that the blast was going to open up a hole in the ocean floor and all these other things.
The bomb went off and it was one of the most fabulously beautiful things, awe-inspiring I've ever seen.
The first sound I heard after the bomb went off was a
young enlisted man in an absolutely odd voice say, geez, just like a pair of lady skivvies.
It was the most beautiful colors in that morning sunrise you've ever seen.
To him, that was about the most appropriate thing to compare this color to.
It was probably the most, I don't
momentous thing I would ever see or ever will see was that bomb going off at six miles away and the first thing I heard was a beautiful remark.
Then after the bomb then you come to the oceanographic office.
I assume it's Fleming then who makes the original contact with you?
Yes, that's right.
And had you known him prior to?
No.
I'm really not sure why he got in touch with me now that you ask that after all these years.
I had accepted a National Research Council Fellowship to go back to school and do some more graduate work when the offer came from him.
I was at Bikini when the offer came, and I had to make a decision whether to join the government or to go back to school.
presented such a challenge to develop the first really major oceanographic activity in the federal government.
And it was.
It was the only, in fact.
Office of Naval Research was under the Dr. Revell's leadership.
He was the head, along with Mary
editor of Deep Sea Research, worked at Woods Hole, works at Woods Hole Oceanic, Mary Sears, S-E-A-R-S, and she was a commander of the Navy, and she and Captain Revell at that time
ran the oceanographic office in the Navy hydrographic office before Fleming took over.
It was just an interesting challenge about the only.
How did you perceive your job when you first arrived there?
What sort of things did you want to do?
This is before the famous tenure plan.
Oh, gosh, yes.
I don't know.
I was so fresh out of school.
The only job I'd ever really had was the job with the school I mentioned as instructor in the radar school, and then going directly with the Woods Hole Oceanographic.
And I knew from my experiences on destroyers and submarines and that bikini that I had fallen completely in love with the ocean, that it was just to be my whole life.
imagine a life not involved with the oceans.
And so Dr. Fleming indicated that one of the plans for the new Division of Oceanography at the Hydrographic Office was to obtain some seagoing vessels.
And so I saw an opportunity to have my cake and eat it, and to get back to sea, of course.
Did you not, you first commissioned two vessels, is that correct?

Well, after we formed the Division of Oceanography and we began working with the Navy, because it was the Navy Hydrographic Office at that time, we worked with Admiral Momsen and the Submarine Force, the editor of the Momsen Long, and Admiral Grenfell and
some officers that I had known, and this is a marine force, during the war.
And Dr. Byrnes prepared a chart to show for the North Atlantic, the areas that we simply had no oceanographic knowledge whatsoever.
And most of them were in the North Atlantic in the winter, which I didn't quite realize this significance of.
So we got two AVPs.
These are the
big ex-coast guard seaplane tenders.
And Dr. Lyman and I designed the alterations to convert these two big ships into oceanographic research vessels.
And that was the San Pablo and the Rehoboth.
And we then spent
Let's see, until 1951, I was at an International Union of Geology and Geophysics meeting in Europe.
I had just come back from a cruise in the Arctic on the icebreaker Edisto.
Fallen completely in love with the Arctic, now on top of enjoying going to sea.
The Arctic was so fabulously beautiful.
And I could see so many interesting problems on ice, icebergs and ice formation.
Came home from that long cruise up around Yanmeyan and into what now would be considered as the Russian waters.
Then went to Europe and came home and immediately got a polio.
That kind of changed my plans.

And while I was in Europe, I was offered a job at the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries Laboratory in Hawaii to work on the oceanography of the tropical Pacific and other distribution of the Tunas, pure descriptive oceanography.
So while I was on the San Pablo and the Rehoboth, and having had some experience, which so few people had,
I went on these cruises as a senior scientist.
I mention that only that I was able to essentially plan the cruises to meet the needs of all of the areas of the Atlantic that we knew so little about.
And I was able, because of my years with Woods Hole,

work with Val Worthington and Fritz Fuglister and Dean Pompous and people at Woods Hole who were so knowledgeable about the North Atlantic and about seagoing techniques and about equipment and sampling.
They went out with me on the early cruises to train me, and we had a cadre of enlisted men, a hydrographic division, it was called, on the ship under an ensign.
And these young lads were the ones who worked with us as civilians, too.
occupy the stations and the ships worked together.
Ship A and Ship B would be on station and Ship A would go here and Ship B would go here and Ship A would go here and Ship B would go here.
This went on week after week, month after month.
We worked from Philadelphia to Iceland to
Scapa Flow in Scotland, to Plymouth, to Gibraltar, to the Azores, to the Canary Islands, areas that just nobody had ever worked before since the days of the Carnegie and the Challenger and so forth.
So when I did get polio, I was able to
to use all of this knowledge and experience at a desk.
So I did go to Hawaii in 1952 with the oceanographic program at the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries Lab and stayed there until 62 as their chief oceanographer and then the assistant director.

62, I had an offer to come to Washington to develop a laboratory that would have its base on Virginia Key in Miami to be the Bureau's, Department of Interior's, major oceanographic and fishery research lab in the southeastern United States.
So after 10 years in Hawaii, I decided to come back to Washington.
